unnormalised: A frantic call came into the Delhi Fire Service at 3:17 AM on 12/07/2024 reporting a major fire at ABC Hospital in Karol Bagh. Initial reports indicated that the fire originated in the ICU on the 2nd floor, potentially due to a short circuit. Within minutes, 8 fire tenders were dispatched to the scene, battling heavy smoke and flames that quickly engulfed the ward.
normalised: A frantic call came into the Delhi Fire Service at three seventeen A M on twelfth july two thousand and twenty four reporting a major fire at A-B-C Hospital in Karol Bagh. Initial reports indicated that the fire originated in the I-C-U on the second floor, potentially due to a short circuit. Within minutes, eight fire tenders were dispatched to the scene, battling heavy smoke and flames that quickly engulfed the ward.

unnormalised: Dr. Rajesh Kumar, a junior resident on night duty, recounted the chaos. "It was terrifying. The fire spread so fast. We had patients on ventilators, needing immediate evacuation. I remember shouting 'Fire! Fire!' and trying to move as many as possible." He managed to help 3 patients, including one with severe COPD, before the thick smoke forced him to retreat.

unnormalised: The rescue operation was hampered by narrow corridors and panicked relatives. The Delhi Police cordoned off the area, managing the crowd while paramedics from AIIMS and Lady Hardinge Medical College rushed to provide aid. Tragically, 7 patients, including a 68-year-old man awaiting heart surgery and a newborn in the NICU, were declared dead at the scene. Approximately 20 others sustained burns, some with 40% BSA, and were transported to nearby hospitals.

unnormalised: An investigation is underway to determine the exact cause of the fire. Preliminary findings suggest that faulty wiring and a lack of adequate fire safety measures may have contributed to the tragedy. The hospital’s license is under review, and the Delhi government has announced a compensation of Rs. 5 lakh for the families of the deceased. The Health Minister has promised a thorough audit of all hospitals in the city to prevent such incidents in the future.
